questions.question_text: Which command would be used to deploy a Tanzu Kubernetes cluster?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
I've seen about three questions in this dump like this. It's always "apply -F <file>". The -F parameter is required because that tells kubectl to read the config from a file. 

Go with "C" or whichever answer has "apply -F"

Selected Answer: AE
A&E - You must have DRS and HA enabled to deploy workload management.

Selected Answer: AE
I don't agree with ExamTopics, I believe it is A + E. Here's why. 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-EE236215-DA4D-4579-8BEB-A693D1882C77.html

According to that, HA and DRS are needed. That's A&E. 

That document also bears no mention of three distinct subnets being required, so we can possibly disregard "D". 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-C3048E95-6E9D-4AC3-BE96-44446D288A7D.html

According to that, DHCP is optional, so we should disregard B & C.

comments.content:
I keep thinking about the number of subnets needed for a supervisor cluster, and this article can help: 

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-A3EEF5E4-3FAB-4193-B924-5579716D112A.html

Again here we don't see a requirement for three subnets. I think "D" is an incorrect answer for sure.

questions.question_text:
An administrator is configuring a vSphere with Tanzu Supervisor Cluster with the vSphere networking stack.

Which two minimum requirements must be met for the compute and networking components? (Choose two.)

choices.D: A minimum of three distinct subnets
choices.B: A DHCP IP address range for the Kubernetes control plane VMs
choices.C: A DHCP IP address range for the HA Proxy virtual IPs
choices.E: The cluster configured with vSphere DRS enabled and automation level set to Fully Automated
choices.A: The cluster configured with vSphere High Availability enabled

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Easy one, answer is B. Let's go: 

A. Datastore Cluster - No, this is a storage construct in VSphere that aggregates datastores. Has nothing to do directly with PVs. 
B. Storage Class - Yes, PVC's are associated with a storage class (defined by a VSphere storage policy)
C. vVols - No, this is a volume virtualisation technology used at the hypervisor layer in VSphere and again doesn't have anything to do with PVs
D. Persistent Volume Claim - This is how we get the PV, but the question asks how we define the type of storage backing it... SC is a better answer.

questions.question_text: Which element defines the type of storage backing the Persistent Volume?
At which three levels of the vSphere Client is information about Kubernetes Persistent Volumes found? (Choose three.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: BCD
I'm not really sure about this question exactly because who goes looking for this information about your containers in the VCenter objects? Anyway we can derive the three correct answers through elimination. 

A. Resource Pool - No, this is for CPU and RAM
E. Virtual Machine - If you looked at the VM representing a node, you wouldn't see any storage info pertaining to PVs, it's abstracted (and First Class Disks are unassociated from VMs!) 
F. Network - Huh, no

That leaves just B, C, and D.

questions.question_text: Which summary page should an administrator use in the vSphere Client to identify the CPU resources consumed in a namespace?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
It's B

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/7.0/vmware-vsphere-with-tanzu/GUID-A78F1D03-4875-40B5-8A57-EF8F07C03CEF.html

A. ESXi host - No, this won't show you Tanzu information
B. Namespace - Yes, read the linked document, it clearly shows CPU
C. vSphere cluster - No, but sort of almost close
D. Supervisor Cluster - No, this is just the workload enabled cluster.
